title: Typhoon Kajiki forces more than 500,000 to evacuate in Vietnam
description: Flights grounded and streets deserted as country braces for ‘extremely dangerous’ typhoon to hit
content:
Vietnam has ordered more than half a million people to evacuate as Typhoon Kajiki barrels towards the country with gales as strong as 100 miles per hour.

The storm skirted China’s southern coast of Hainan Island late on Sunday, before racing towards Vietnam – where the memory of Typhoon Yagi, a devastating storm that killed at least 300 people last year, looms large.

The latest typhoon is due to hit at around 1pm local time on Monday (7am BST) and state media said 586,000 people in the central provinces of Thanh Hoa, Quang Tri, Hue and Da Nang have been ordered to leave their homes as the country braces for impact.

Flights have also been grounded, boats banned from leaving the harbour, and troops deployed to assist with relief operations.

AFP reported that the streets in waterfront cities were largely deserted on Monday morning, with homes and businesses surrounded by sandbags.

“The situation is extremely dangerous and not safe for any vehicles or structures such as tourism or fishing vessels and aquaculture raising facilities,” an official from the ministry of agriculture and environment told the news agency.
summary: Vietnam has ordered over 500,000 people to evacuate due to Typhoon Kajiki, which is expected to hit the country at around 1pm local time on Monday. The storm has already impacted the central provinces of Thanh Hoa, Quang Tri, Hue and Da Nang, with flights grounded and troops deployed to assist with relief operations.
shortSummary: Vietnam has ordered over 500,000 people to leave their homes as Typhoon Kajiki approaches, causing disruption to transport and power supplies.
